title: Colorado dermatology company warning about cybersecurity threat where hacker gained access to health information - Summit Daily
text:
Colorado dermatology company warning about cybersecurity threat where hacker gained access to health information
The dermatology company that serves Summit and Eagle counties says impacted individuals should remain vigilant for fraud and identity theft
A Colorado dermatology company is warning about a cybersecurity breach which may have resulted in unauthorized disclosure of people’ protected healthcare and personal information.
About two months ago, Mountain Dermatology Specialists, which has locations in Edwards and Dillon, discovered that a hacker had gained access to an employee’s email account, according to a Dec. 22 news release from the company.
After first discovering the unauthorized access on Oct. 26, Mountain Dermatology learned that the hacker used the account to send phishing emails to the mailbox’s contacts, so the company took immediate steps to secure the account and investigate the incident, the release states.
With the assistance of cybersecurity professionals, the dermatology company in late November determined that the hacker had access to the email account from Oct. 24-26 and could have acquired emails in the mailbox, according to the release.
Mountain Dermatology reportedly analyzed the contents of all emails in the account to identify all potentially impacted individuals and the types of information involved. On Dec. 22, the company sent notice letters to impacted individuals for whom it had a current mailing address, the release states.
The protected information involved may have included anything from an individual’s full name, address, date of birth, phone number, email address, dates of treatment, type of treatment condition, diagnosis, medications and health insurance information such as costs and amounts paid, according to Mountain Dermatology. For a small number of people, the cybersecurity incident reportedly also involved social security numbers or compensation and benefits information.
Mountain Dermatology has been enhancing its cybersecurity protections since the incident occurred, including by working with IT professionals to implement password resets and increased monitoring, the release states. The dermatology company says it reported the cybersecurity incident to law enforcement.
Those who may have had information involved in the incident should remain vigilant to the possibility of fraud and identity theft by regularly reviewing their financial statements, credit reports and explanation of benefits from health insurers for any unauthorized activity, according to Mountain Dermatology.
If an individual identifies services that they did not receive or accounts, charges or withdrawals that they did not authorize, they should report the involved company or credit reporting agency immediately, the release states.
Individuals can obtain information about placing fraud alerts and security freezes from the Federal Trade Commission and the three national credit reporting agencies, Equifax Fraud Reporting, Experian Fraud Reporting and TransUnion Fraud Reporting.
Mountain Dermatology has also arranged for individuals with information involved in the cybersecurity incident to have complimentary access to identity restoration services and to fraud detection tools for 12 months, the release states. Individuals have until March 15 to active complimentary fraud detection tools, according to the release.
Mountain Dermatology has partnered with Experian’s customer care team to set up a toll-free call center at 855-223-4826 to help answer questions. Those who did not receive a notice letter but believe their information could have been involved should contact the call center, which is open Monday through Friday from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m. Callers should be prepared to provide their engagement number B112377, the release states.
